transcript: [Visual: Speaker introduces the topic of startup financing myths, highlighting that it's not all about money and emphasizing the importance of investors bringing more than just money, and introduces the second myth about the order of pitch deck slides.] [Visual: A man in glasses and a jacket gestures in front of a background with the words 'START-UP FINANCING MYTH UNVEILED' and a person working on a laptop in the background.] : Today, I'm busting 7 myths about startup financing. [Visual: White screen with the text 'TEAM SLIDE FIRST'.] [Visual: Speaker explains the importance of starting with the investment thesis, then introduces the third myth about pitch structure, clarifying that pitches are either data-driven or concept-driven and need to be tailored accordingly.] : I would not do this. [Visual: A man in a grey jacket speaks to the camera with two people in the background.] : In fact, you need to start with your investment thesis. : Grab investors' attention with what they need to believe first. [Visual: A person looks at a screen showing two figures in boxes connected by a curved arrow.] : Myth 3: all pitches follow the same structure. [Visual: A man wearing glasses and a jacket is speaking directly to the camera.] : Not true. [Visual: A close-up of a man with glasses speaking directly to the camera, with text overlay: "NOT TRUE, YOUR PITCH IS".] : Your pitch is either data-driven or concept-driven. [Visual: A woman in a yellow suit stands in front of a screen with complex diagrams and glowing lines, with text overlay: "OR CONCEPT DRIVEN."] : Know which one you're pitching.

hashtags: reidhoffman, StartUp, entrepreneur, business, innovation, startup

transcript: [Visual: A man with glasses introduces the topic by discussing general founder advice to ask what's wrong with your product and sets the stage for a story about LinkedIn proving a smart VC wrong.] [Visual: A man with glasses is shown in front of a title that reads "HOW LINKEDIN PROVED A SMART VC WRONG."] : General founder advice is ask what's wrong with your product. transcript: [Visual: Speaker explains the initial success of the Airbnb pitch by highlighting its eBay-like concept for space and the massive potential of the travel industry.] [Visual: A man wearing glasses and a brown shirt is speaking in front of an Airbnb ad.] [Visual: Speaker discusses how the pitch explained the product's value, margins, defensible position, and growth potential.] : The reasons why the Airbnb pitch was really good from the beginning is like, "Well, we're eBay for space, and we're starting with travel, and travel itself is huge." This is what the dynamics work in terms of opening up liquidity between host and traveler. [Visual: Speaker emphasizes how quickly the core concept of the pitch became understandable.] [Visual: An image of a map with a phone.] [Visual: Speaker notes that the claim of having no competition is typically not believable.] : "Oh, well, charging people like this, this is why the product will be good, this is why we'll have good margins, this is why we'll have a defensible position, this is why we'll be a big size, and this is why we'll be growing." And you're like, "Okay, I get it." That was one of the pitches, literally 2 minutes in, and you're like, "Okay, I understand." To claim 0 competition is usually not credible.
description: Airbnb’s pitch winning strategy
hashtags: reidhoffman, StartUp, entrepreneur, business, innovation, startup

transcript: [Visual: Speaker explains that LinkedIn's initial product launch was basic with limited features, and the lack of value for early users was part of the blitzscaling technique; SpeakerA: "Part of the techniques for blitzscaling LinkedIn, one was launch a product that embarrasses you on your first release."; SpeakerB: "The LinkedIn product launch was a very basic profile, a very basic search mechanism, and an ability to communicate through the people you were connected with, and that's it."; SpeakerB: "And part of the problem for this kind of network property is there was no value for the first person, the second person, third person."] [Visual: A man in a gray shirt and black blazer stands in front of a title that reads 'HOW DID LINKEDIN BECOME VALUABLE?'] : Part of the techniques for blitzscaling LinkedIn, one was launch a product that embarrasses you on your first release. [Visual: A man in a black blazer speaks with his hands in front of a blue background.] : The LinkedIn product launch was a very basic profile, a very basic search mechanism, and an ability to communicate through the people you were connected with, and that's it. : And part of the problem for this kind of network property is there was no value for the first person, the second person, third person. [Visual: Speaker discusses how value increased with user growth, emphasizing the strategy of early release and iterative product development: "Value really only started happening once you had the 500,000th or the 1000000th person, and so how do you get there in terms of doing it?" and "What I told the team was, 'What we really need to do is get the product out there, see what the reactions are, and use that to inform our theory about what's next most important.' And for a year, we were building a whole bunch of other things, you know."] : Value really only started happening once you had the 500,000th or the 1000000th person, and so how do you get there in terms of doing it? [Visual: A man in a black blazer speaks with his hands in front of a blue background.] : What I told the team was, "What we really need to do is get the product out there, see what the reactions are, and use that to inform our theory about what's next most important." And for a year, we were building a whole bunch of other things, you know. [Visual: A team meeting shows the development progress; and by the time they reached a million users, the network started becoming valuable: "And by that time, we'd gotten to, you know, like a million people in the network, and it started being valuable."] [Visual: The top half of the screen shows a group of people looking at a laptop screen, and the bottom half shows a man speaking in front of a blue background.] : And by that time, we'd gotten to, you know, like a million people in the network, and it started being valuable.
description: How did LinkedIn become valuable?

transcript: [Visual: Speaker introduces AI's potential to transform lives, emphasizing the concept of a personal intelligence that assists with various daily tasks and conversations.] : AI is going to transform industries, companies, but also the ability for individuals to have really quality lives. : Everyone's going to have a personal intelligence. : Everyone's going to have a, kind of an assistant that kind of covers everything from, "Hey, I've got these 7 things in my fridge. [Visual: Several attractive people are posed in front of a digitally altered background with stars.] : What can I make for dinner?" To, "My blender's broken. [Visual: A man holding a cell phone looks into an open refrigerator.] : Is there anything I can do to fix it?" To, you know, "I had this odd conversation with my brother or sister and I kind of want to unpack it." To, you know, "Here's what I'm thinking about doing when I'm at work," or engagement I'm doing, and who's my personal intelligence who helps me navigate with it? [Visual: Speaker highlights that the AI assistant is personal, not controlled by a company.] : Not the company's, but mine. [Visual: Speaker clarifies that AI is designed to assist humans, not to replace them.] : It is not meant to replace human beings and human beings' lives.
description: How AI can solve most of our problems

transcript: [Visual: Speaker speaks to the camera, stating that current innovations are beneficial for the world.] [Visual: A man with glasses and earbuds speaks directly to the camera, with the text 'AND THE ELEMENTS OF' overlaid on the image.] [Visual: Speaker discusses the 'innovator's dilemma', noting that people often prefer direct answers over multiple search results.] : I think that's good for the world and all the rest. [Visual: Speaker comments on the tech company's reaction, mentioning their feeling of having no competition for over a decade.] : I do think they have a bit of a innovator's dilemma problem 'cause, you know, people would kind of rather have an answer than 10 blue links in a lot of cases and you, you see some of the thrashing about trying to figure that out, which is part of the thing and, you know, it's good for them. [Visual: Speaker concludes that having competition is positive for the market.] : I mean, they, they basically spent, you know, a decade plus feeling like they didn't have any competition and, you know, now having a game on i- is good for the marketplace.
description: Is Google hopelessly behind with the rise of AI?
hashtags: reidhoffman, innovation, ai, google, Tech, tech

transcript: [Visual: A man in a suit emphasizes the significance of being the first to scale, highlighting Uber's strategy to launch in multiple cities simultaneously.] [Visual: A man in a suit is speaking in front of a background that reads 'THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING FIRST'.] : first to scale really matters. [Visual: A man in a black suit is sitting on a chair and talking in front of a background that reads 'COMMONWEALTH CLUB', with the words 'First to SCALE' superimposed on the image.] : Uber is a classic example, like, oh gosh, we gotta launch tons and tons of cities simultaneously 'cause it's mostly within a city. [Visual: A man speaking on a chair in a blue background.] : With Slack, it's how do we go to enterprise grade? : And how do we start being an enterprise product even though we have this kind of viral adoption with what's going on? [Visual: The speaker discusses the need to scale for business viability, mentioning PayPal's competition and its requirement of a minimum GMV for success, and how to become an enterprise product.] : Sometimes it's- we need to get to scale in order for the business to work. [Visual: A man speaking on a chair with a background showing a road and buildings.] : Like even if we hadn't had kind of competition, which we did, with PayPal. [Visual: A man speaking on a chair in a blue background.] : PayPal payment services generally speaking don't work unless they're a minimum of like a billion dollars GMV.
description: The importance of being first #entrepreneurship #reidhoffman #foryou

transcript: [Visual: The video introduces Zuckerberg's hiring heuristic: hire people you'd work for, including the question of whether you would learn from them and going into battle together.] [Visual: A man with glasses is in the foreground, with the words 'HIRE PEOPLE YOU'D WORK FOR' in the background.] : In the interview I did with Zuckerberg, he gave a good heuristic, which is, hire people you'd work for. [Visual: A split screen shows a man in glasses talking at the top, and Mark Zuckerberg talking at the bottom.] : And it's a good question to ask yourself: Is this person someone I would learn from? [Visual: A blurred background shows two people sitting and talking during an event.] : Someone that, as we're going into battle, we would be learning from each other? [Visual: The video stresses disciplined hiring practices and the importance of teamwork to maintain a high bar in a difficult situation.] : And those kinds of things that are encapsulated in that metric of what I hire somebody I would work for, is a good way of trying to be very disciplined about keeping the bar high in who you're joining, because, you know, you're going into this really important thing that's g- very difficult, and you need to have the team with you. [Visual: The video highlights the significant time commitment with colleagues and the need to be willing to "go into battle" with them, concluding with final thoughts on hiring.] [Visual: Several people sit around a table with a laptop.] : And these are people you're gonna be spending hours and hours and hours with. [Visual: A man and a woman sit and talk during an event.] : You'd want to be going into battle with them.
description: Good advice from Mark Zuckerberg: Hire people you'd work for

transcript: [Visual: A man in front of a blue background introduces the topic with the title "WHAT AI REVEALS ABOUT HUMANITY", then the man with glasses discusses the negative perception of animal intelligence, highlighting their complex behaviors like pair bonding and coordination.] [Visual: The image shows a man in front of a blue background with text overlay, with the title "WHAT AI REVEALS ABOUT HUMANITY" in bold text.] : We're very anthropocentric. [Visual: A man wearing glasses is sitting on a wooden chair discussing anthropocentric views in front of a wooden background.] : We generally are very negative on, like, how other animals think. : And, like, they think a lot more than we think they do. [Visual: The image shows a close-up shot of a dog.] : I mean, they pair bond, they mate for life, they coordinate in packs and groups. [Visual: The video introduces machine thinking, shows a robotic arm, and discusses how AI thinks differently from humans, emphasizing that machines are capable of thinking, though not necessarily in the same way as humans.] : Well, now we also have another pattern of thinking. [Visual: The image shows a graphic of a brain against a dark background with the text 'Well, now we also have'.] : How do these machines think? [Visual: A robotic arm is seen in action, with the question 'How do these machines think?' overlayed on the scene.] : 'Cause, by the way, they are thinking today too. : They're not thinking the way we are. [Visual: The image shows a large AI text graphic against a dark background with the text 'they are thinking'.] : They may not be thinking at our level of capability in some- Mm-hmm. : regards.
description: How humans think differently from other animals—and from AI

transcript: [Visual: Speaker discusses hardware product launches and how the team hesitated to launch LinkedIn due to a lack of features, with the woman in pink blazer saying "Okay. Right?" and mentioning the desired inclusion of Contact Finder.] [Visual: A man with glasses speaks into a microphone, discussing a hardware product.] : If you were launching a hardware product and you're embarrassed, you're probably dead. : And when we launched LinkedIn, basically my whole team didn't want to launch. [Visual: The scene shows the LinkedIn logo on a geometric background with an animated hand touching it.] [Visual: A woman in a pink blazer laughs while speaking into a microphone.] : Okay. : Right? : They were like, "There's not enough features yet. [Visual: Animated LinkedIn logo on a cube with a grid and floating text 'There's not a feature check'.] : There's not enough to do." There was a feature that they had really wanted to include called Contact Finder, which is an ability to say to your network, "I'm looking for a person who can help me edit a podcast," or something.
description: If you're not embarrassed by your product at launch, you've probably launched too late
